div.output_wrapper {
  /* this position must be relative to enable descendents to be absolute within it */
  position: relative;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  z-index: 1;
}
/* class for the output area when it should be height-limited */
div.output_scroll {
  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;
  /* FF needs this *and the wrapper* to specify full width, or it will shrinkwrap */
  width: 100%;
  overflow: auto;
  border-radius: 2px;
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  display: block;
}
/* output div while it is collapsed */
div.output_collapsed {
  margin: 0px;
  padding: 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;

  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */

  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay {
  height: 100%;
  padding: 0px 0.4em;
  position: absolute;
  border-radius: 2px;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay:hover {
  /* use inner shadow to get border that is computed the same on WebKit/FF */
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  background: rgba(240, 240, 240, 0.5);
}
div.output_prompt {

</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This is an example using 'fake' data for the difference between lmer (which assumes a constant (independent) covariance matrix for the error terms)
and geepack (general estimating equations, which can handle an unknown convariance structure))</p>
<p>This example highlights the power of using a GEE model over a HLM model when the covariance structure differs at different levels of the data. 
The GEE model can be seen as a population estimating model -- i.e., it is preferable when we are trying to make inferences about the population rather than the individuals in the sample. We do not explicitly parametrize over the groups -- instead, we assign some covariance structure between members of each group and find the marginal distribution.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The problem is formulated as follows: consider 6 athletes with characteristics given by:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span><span class="nf">library</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lme4</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="nf">library</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">geepack</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stderr output_text">
<pre><span class="code-line">Loading required package: Matrix</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span><span class="n">athlete</span><span class="o"><-</span><span class="nf">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">6</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">6</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">6</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="n">age</span><span class="o"><-</span><span class="nf">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">38</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">40</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">43</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">53</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">55</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">56</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">58</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">37</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">40</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">42</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">41</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">45</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">46</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">54</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">58</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">57</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">60</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">62</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="n">club</span><span class="o"><-</span><span class="nf">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="n">time</span><span class="o"><-</span><span class="nf">c</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">95</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">94</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">93</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">96</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">98</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">91</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">93</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">83</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">82</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">82</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">91</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">94</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">99</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">105</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">111</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">90</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">89</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="m">95</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="n">logtime</span><span class="o"><-</span><span class="nf">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">time</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This is an example of a repeated measures problem.</p>
<p>We create a dataframe from these elements:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span><span class="n">df</span><span class="o"><-</span><span class="nf">data.frame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">athlete</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">age</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">club</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">time</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">logtime</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="n">df</span></span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<table>
<thead><tr><th scope=col>athlete</th><th scope=col>age</th><th scope=col>club</th><th scope=col>time</th><th scope=col>logtime</th></tr></thead>
<tbody>
	<tr><td>1       </td><td>38      </td><td>0       </td><td> 95     </td><td>4.553877</td></tr>
	<tr><td>1       </td><td>40      </td><td>0       </td><td> 94     </td><td>4.543295</td></tr>
	<tr><td>1       </td><td>43      </td><td>1       </td><td> 93     </td><td>4.532599</td></tr>
	<tr><td>2       </td><td>53      </td><td>1       </td><td> 96     </td><td>4.564348</td></tr>
	<tr><td>2       </td><td>55      </td><td>1       </td><td> 98     </td><td>4.584967</td></tr>
	<tr><td>2       </td><td>56      </td><td>1       </td><td> 91     </td><td>4.510860</td></tr>
	<tr><td>2       </td><td>58      </td><td>1       </td><td> 93     </td><td>4.532599</td></tr>
	<tr><td>3       </td><td>37      </td><td>1       </td><td> 83     </td><td>4.418841</td></tr>
	<tr><td>3       </td><td>40      </td><td>1       </td><td> 82     </td><td>4.406719</td></tr>
	<tr><td>3       </td><td>42      </td><td>0       </td><td> 82     </td><td>4.406719</td></tr>
	<tr><td>4       </td><td>41      </td><td>0       </td><td> 91     </td><td>4.510860</td></tr>
	<tr><td>4       </td><td>45      </td><td>1       </td><td> 94     </td><td>4.543295</td></tr>
	<tr><td>4       </td><td>46      </td><td>0       </td><td> 99     </td><td>4.595120</td></tr>
	<tr><td>5       </td><td>54      </td><td>1       </td><td>105     </td><td>4.653960</td></tr>
	<tr><td>5       </td><td>58      </td><td>1       </td><td>111     </td><td>4.709530</td></tr>
	<tr><td>6       </td><td>57      </td><td>1       </td><td> 90     </td><td>4.499810</td></tr>
	<tr><td>6       </td><td>60      </td><td>1       </td><td> 89     </td><td>4.488636</td></tr>
	<tr><td>6       </td><td>62      </td><td>1       </td><td> 95     </td><td>4.553877</td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>

</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now, we want to estimate the (log) time based on age and club. However, the data is clearly correlated -- each individual will have different 
specifications. Consider that we believe that the average (log) time will be different for each individual, as a baseline. This is a mixed model
more specifically a Random Intercept model. This is highlighted by the following equations.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span><span class="n">mod1</span><span class="o"><-</span><span class="nf">lmer</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logtime</span><span class="o">~</span><span class="n">club</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="nf">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">age</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="o">|</span><span class="n">athlete</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">REML</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">FALSE</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="n">mod2</span><span class="o"><-</span><span class="nf">lmer</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logtime</span><span class="o">~</span><span class="nf">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">age</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="m">1</span><span class="o">|</span><span class="n">athlete</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">REML</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">FALSE</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="nf">summary</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mod1</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="nf">summary</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mod2</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea ">
<pre><span class="code-line">Linear mixed model fit by maximum likelihood  ['lmerMod']</span>
<span class="code-line">Formula: logtime ~ club + log(age) + (1 | athlete)</span>
<span class="code-line">   Data: df</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">     AIC      BIC   logLik deviance df.resid </span>
<span class="code-line">   -49.2    -44.7     29.6    -59.2       13 </span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Scaled residuals: </span>
<span class="code-line">    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max </span>
<span class="code-line">-1.3445 -0.7551 -0.1840  0.7895  1.2651 </span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Random effects:</span>
<span class="code-line"> Groups   Name        Variance  Std.Dev.</span>
<span class="code-line"> athlete  (Intercept) 0.0042173 0.06494 </span>
<span class="code-line"> Residual             0.0008858 0.02976 </span>
<span class="code-line">Number of obs: 18, groups:  athlete, 6</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Fixed effects:</span>
<span class="code-line">            Estimate Std. Error t value</span>
<span class="code-line">(Intercept)  3.78158    0.45714   8.272</span>
<span class="code-line">club        -0.01049    0.02101  -0.499</span>
<span class="code-line">log(age)     0.19753    0.11837   1.669</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Correlation of Fixed Effects:</span>
<span class="code-line">         (Intr) club  </span>
<span class="code-line">club      0.184       </span>
<span class="code-line">log(age) -0.998 -0.216</pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea ">
<pre><span class="code-line">Linear mixed model fit by maximum likelihood  ['lmerMod']</span>
<span class="code-line">Formula: logtime ~ log(age) + (1 | athlete)</span>
<span class="code-line">   Data: df</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">     AIC      BIC   logLik deviance df.resid </span>
<span class="code-line">   -50.9    -47.4     29.5    -58.9       14 </span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Scaled residuals: </span>
<span class="code-line">    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max </span>
<span class="code-line">-1.3343 -0.6924 -0.3215  0.7936  1.2927 </span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Random effects:</span>
<span class="code-line"> Groups   Name        Variance  Std.Dev.</span>
<span class="code-line"> athlete  (Intercept) 0.0042948 0.06554 </span>
<span class="code-line"> Residual             0.0008962 0.02994 </span>
<span class="code-line">Number of obs: 18, groups:  athlete, 6</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Fixed effects:</span>
<span class="code-line">            Estimate Std. Error t value</span>
<span class="code-line">(Intercept)   3.8241     0.4527   8.448</span>
<span class="code-line">log(age)      0.1846     0.1164   1.586</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Correlation of Fixed Effects:</span>
<span class="code-line">         (Intr)</span>
<span class="code-line">log(age) -0.998</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>However, this assumes that the covariance structure of the errors at each level are independent. This assumption is too simplifying -- 
it is likely that the variables are correlated across individuals (for instance, it appears that the clubs are for particular age ranges). To account for this, we could add more random effects to the model (which would subsequently break the data down into even smaller groups), or we could use a GEE to forgo the subject-level estimations and estimate on the populations, assuming some covariance structure between groups.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-r"><pre><span class="code-line"><span></span><span class="n">mod3</span><span class="o"><-</span><span class="nf">geeglm</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logtime</span><span class="o">~</span><span class="n">club</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="nf">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">age</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">athlete</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">family</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">gaussian</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">corstr</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"exchangeable"</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="n">mod4</span><span class="o"><-</span><span class="nf">geeglm</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">logtime</span><span class="o">~</span><span class="nf">log</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">age</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">df</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">athlete</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">family</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">gaussian</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">corstr</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"exchangeable"</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="nf">summary</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mod3</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
<span class="code-line"><span class="nf">summary</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mod4</span><span class="p">)</span></span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea ">
<pre><span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Call:</span>
<span class="code-line">geeglm(formula = logtime ~ club + log(age), family = gaussian, </span>
<span class="code-line">    data = df, id = athlete, corstr = "exchangeable")</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line"> Coefficients:</span>
<span class="code-line">            Estimate  Std.err   Wald Pr(>|W|)    </span>
<span class="code-line">(Intercept)  3.67345  0.42962 73.109   <2e-16 ***</span>
<span class="code-line">club        -0.01429  0.01422  1.010   0.3149    </span>
<span class="code-line">log(age)     0.22584  0.11276  4.011   0.0452 *  </span>
<span class="code-line">---</span>
<span class="code-line">Signif. codes:  0 *** 0.001 ** 0.01 * 0.05 . 0.1   1</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Estimated Scale Parameters:</span>
<span class="code-line">            Estimate  Std.err</span>
<span class="code-line">(Intercept) 0.004443 0.001609</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Correlation: Structure = exchangeable  Link = identity </span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Estimated Correlation Parameters:</span>
<span class="code-line">      Estimate Std.err</span>
<span class="code-line">alpha   0.6112  0.1829</span>
<span class="code-line">Number of clusters:   6   Maximum cluster size: 4 </pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea ">
<pre><span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Call:</span>
<span class="code-line">geeglm(formula = logtime ~ log(age), family = gaussian, data = df, </span>
<span class="code-line">    id = athlete, corstr = "exchangeable")</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line"> Coefficients:</span>
<span class="code-line">            Estimate Std.err  Wald Pr(>|W|)    </span>
<span class="code-line">(Intercept)    3.742   0.488 58.84  1.7e-14 ***</span>
<span class="code-line">log(age)       0.206   0.127  2.61     0.11    </span>
<span class="code-line">---</span>
<span class="code-line">Signif. codes:  0 *** 0.001 ** 0.01 * 0.05 . 0.1   1</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Estimated Scale Parameters:</span>
<span class="code-line">            Estimate Std.err</span>
<span class="code-line">(Intercept)  0.00458 0.00154</span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Correlation: Structure = exchangeable  Link = identity </span>
<span class="code-line"></span>
<span class="code-line">Estimated Correlation Parameters:</span>
<span class="code-line">      Estimate Std.err</span>
<span class="code-line">alpha    0.624   0.181</span>
<span class="code-line">Number of clusters:   6   Maximum cluster size: 4 </pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The main shift in inference here is from likelihood models (which are generally prefered) to a semi-parametric model that depends only on the
first two moments. GEEs are better estimators of a population-level variance -- they cannot account for individual differences explicitly, as a GLMM could. In this example, however, we see that the GEE finds the log(age) value significant where the previous model had not. Depending on the 
goal of the analysis, the GEE will produce better estimates asymptotically at the cost of sample-level inference.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
